item.description: The board has a large picture of a leopard without spots. Before the game, players place black spots with a particular word (all of which make a phrase with the word "spot") face down. Players then draw cards with a word and must find the appropriate spot on the leopard.

Each player gets a grid on which each will write one's words. A specially designed roulette wheel that has seven balls is spun. Instead of the usual numbers, the roulette wheel has letters of the alphabet. Each letter of the alphabet has been assigned a value from one to ten points. Once the seven letters for the round have been determined, the players have a time limit to use those letters in words on their individual grids crossword-style. The player with the most points after a predetermined number of rounds is the winner.

In the official rules in the box-lid, it there is a single crossword grid that is shared by all players, each player taking turns adding to the grid.

One player is red/orange/yellow and the other is green/blue/violet. The winner of the game who places down more of his or her tokens onto the playing board than the opposing player. Each color which is placed on the playing board must always touch an adjoining color in the correct sequence of the spectrum (red may only touch orange, green may only touch yellow and blue, and so on).
The game starts with each player playing their six extreme tiles (red and violet) anywhere on the board, not touching each other. It is from this start the remaining tiles are played.
There is an alternate set of simpler rules for younger children.

item.description:
From the publisher:

Where does your mind go when you witness life's stranger than fiction moments? Find out when you play Quip It!, where players take turns trying to guess which player wrote which quip for bizarre pictures, unusual film clips and other on-screen oddities. The more right guesses you make, the more points you score and the more points you score, the better. Be spontaneous, be unpredictable, be edgy-it doesn't matter, so long as you Quip It! good.

FlipQuest is an exciting role-playing, collectible card game, where you build the gameboard as you play.

Play alone or join your friends, and defeat Orcs, Dragons, and other powerful creatures using wits, skills, and awesome magical weapons, in FlipQuest, the exciting, innovative role-playing card game where players build the game board as they play from unique card decks. Each FlipQuest adventure deck contains a separate, stand-alone game for 1-4 players, and can be combined for more characters, treasures, and monsters.

name.value: FlipQuest: Quest for the Princess' Crystal

item.description:
FlipQuest is an exciting role-playing, collectible card game, where you build the gameboard as you play.

Play alone or join your friends, and defeat Orcs, Dragons, and other powerful creatures using wits, skills, and awesome magical weapons, in FlipQuest, the exciting, innovative role-playing card game where players build the game board as they play from unique card decks. Each FlipQuest adventure deck contains a separate, stand-alone game for 1-4 players, and can be combined for more characters, treasures, and monsters.

http://www3.sympatico.ca/shadowcraft/

Slings and Stones is a strategy boardgame which uses a standard checkerboard with chess and checkers pieces. It can easily be learned and played in a few short minutes, but mastery of the game will take much longer. Each and every move can have huge ramifications, and players will find it extremely difficult to plan more than a couple of rounds in advance.

I stumbled upon this game while skimming through some old journals I found in my grandfather&#65533;s attic. The rules were gleaned from Kardon's writings on the Muighar tribes, and I've tried my best to keep them authentic. However, as Kardon's description of the rules are not very clear, this version may vary slightly from that of antiquity.

As most of you probably don't have access to authentic Muighar Slings and Stones pieces or boards, I've taken the liberty of finding some substitutions. This game can played using a chess board, with 4 pawns and 12 checkers. Pawns represent the slings, and checkers represent the stones.

http://www.darkshadowgames.com/Epic_Registration/register.html 
(Click "Download SLINGS.ZIP" for rules and bits)

Online Play


 Super Duper Games

Epic: Warlords is a strategy wargame of a vast scope, dealing with the rise and fall of civilizations over hundreds of years, and the terrible battles and wars between the races of Elves, Goblins, Dwarves, and Man.

Epic: Warlords depicts an epic war between the ancient races of Man, Elves, Goblins and others for the domination of the world. The game takes place over the course of centuries or even millennia. But it is at the scale where even within this lengthy time frame, individual heroes and individual actions can leave an impact certain to give birth to legends.

This game involves many campaigns, all of indefinite length, within a larger round that involves the growth of populations and cities. And although armies may be large, individuals stand out due to leadership, artifacts, and miracles. At points in the game, you may wonder, 'just how did one hero defeat 3 units of my armies?' But use as reference - rather than the real world - the myths of Hercules, Odysseus, and King Arthur, or the fantasy stories 'The Lord of the Rings' and 'Conan the Barbarian' (at the end of which Conan and a friend kill about 50 mounted enemy knights).

http://www.darkshadowgames.com/Epic_Registration/register.html 
(Click "Download EPIC.ZIP" for rules and bits)

This is a wargame on the battles of Imphal and Kohima 1944.

Published as a magazine game in JagdPanther #11 which has been rereleased in PDF format by Amarillo Design Bureau.

name.value: Goetterdaemmerung: The Fall of Nazi Germany 1945

item.description:
This is a wargame on the final Allied and Soviet offensives to take Nazi Germany in 1945. It has two scenarios, February 1945 and the Downfall (April 1945) scenarios.

Published in JagdPanther magazine #9 which has been rereleased in PDF format by Amarillo Design Bureau.

From the DVG web site:

Overview:
Elves Under Hoof is a light-hearted game of combat at the North Pole. It seems the elves have opened up a crate of ultra-violent video games and played them all night. By morning they had been turned into mindless zombie elves bent on destruction.

Now, it is up to your team of heroic reindeer to gather weapons and battle the crazed elves to save the day!

Key Points:
- Very easy to play.
- Fun for all ages.
- Armed reindeer take on the evil elves.
- Just in time for the holidays!
 (if it is around holiday time when you are reading this)
- Just the thing to remind you of Christmas!
 (if it is not holiday time when you are reading this)
- 4 Scenarios: An Igloo Too Far, Saving Private Reindeer, E-Day, and The Big Red One

Component List:
- Expensive Player Help Sheet
- One Sheet of Full Color counters
- Very cute full-color Map
- Humor-filled rulebook

Target Audience:
This is a great game for both wargamers and non-gamers alike. The game is fast and easy to understand and who doesn’t like throwing hand grenades at elves?

item.description:
A book from Mensa, published by Barnes and Noble (or by Index in the UK), that includes several boards and pieces.

The book contains a number of games:

All Change! - a one player "game" (actually a puzzle),

Puzzle Piracy - A variant of Sorry where players landing on certain squares have to answer Mensa questions,

various Chess problems,

various peg solitaire problems,

Space Strategy Game - an abstract capture game with three different types of pieces on a board consisting of four concentric rings,

three solitaire peg problems by Henry Dudeney,

crossword puzzles,

and a series of Mensa puzzles.

Only Puzzle Piracy and Space Strategy Game could really be considered "board games" in the classic sense.

An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

This game is designed to utilize those plastic cowboy and Indians lying around your house and put them to use in an entry-level wargame.

Goal: Capture your opponent's Fort or Village.

Players try to take tricks to capture the ingredients necessary to complete their secret recipe. Taking a trick requires playing a high card, but if cards are tied, the player who played that value last gets the trick--so there is a HUGE disadvantage in going first.

item.description: Players are trying to save (or destroy) graves in 1880s London cemeteries. Players have secret objectives--playing cards makes the objectives more attainable, BUT--you score points based on cards still in hand when the game is done (so the more you play, the less you score). Worse still, half the cards help, the other half hurt your scoring--but to ditch the bad cards, you have to play them...and potentially hurt your chances of winning in the first place!! Very tricky. (from Jolly Roger Games as reported on boardgamenews.com)

item.description:
An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

Goal of the Game: The player wins who first connects his opposing sides of the board.

Each player 'owns' two opposing sides of the board. It is advised to mark the sides of each player (at least by placing all the pieces of the players on his sides only). The players may decide whether they want to place the board between them with the corners facing to them or whether they want to sit at an right angle with the sides toward them.

At the start of play the board is empty. One player starts the game. The play then alternates.

At each move the player whose turn it is has three options of play:


 He can enter one of his pieces onto the board;
 Move on of his pieces on the board; or
 Capture an opposing piece with one of his own pieces on the board. 


The player wins the game who is the first to get an uninterrupted line from one of his own sides of the board to his other (opposing) side.

Nannon is a reduction of Backgammon to a super-quick game. Nannon reduces the basic concepts of Backgammon to the smallest feasible combination that still retains the idea of Backgammon.

For instance:

Rather than having "stacks" of men on each position, Nannon allows only one man per spot.
Since you can't "stack" men, contiguous groups of 2 or all 3 men of the same team can't be hit.
Each player has only three men, as opposed to the 15 of Backgammon.
Each player gets one die, rather than getting to use two. (Nannon makes use of the fact that each player has her own die.)
The board only has six positions, instead of 24.

Nannon does, however, still provide a doubling cube, which is rather relevant since the individual games of Nannon are so much shorter than those of Backgammon.

name.value: The New Kid's Choices Board Game

item.description:
Applying Biblical Principles to Everyday Situations

You wanted a stereo CD player for your birthday, and made sure that your grandparents knew it. They've given you an encyclopedia program for the family computer instead. What will you say to them?

A student in charge of lunch tickets has given you too many tickets for the money you gave him. What will you do with the extra tickets?

You don't like the clothes your mom buys for you. You prefer denim and T-shirts. What will you tell her?

Making the right choice can be tough. But with the help of Kid's Choices, learning to make the best decisions becomes exciting entertainment!

Grab your family or your friends (or both!) and get ready to come face to face with some of life's toughest decisions, including those involving friendship, forgiveness and obedience. Learn how to base all your decision making on biblical principles (twenty in all, supported by several verses from the popular NIV® translation of the Bible).

Designed for Ages 6 - 12, The New Kid's Choices is great game play for three to six players, and can also be played in teams. Includes colorful game board, six player markers, 150 dilemma cards, 10 principle cards and an instruction/reference booklet.

name.value: Les Aventuriers du Rail: Édition Märklin

item.description:
Ticket to Ride: Märklin is the third installment in Days of Wonder's best-selling Ticket to Ride series. The board for Märklin is based on a map of Germany and each individual card in the deck depicts a different Märklin Trains model. A DVD introducing players to the Märklin line of model trains is included [Edit: DVD no longer included in recent runs.]

Märklin is a heavier version in the TTR series, allowing players to not only travel from city to city but also from cities to countries. A new mechanic is also introduced in the form of passengers and merchandise tokens. When the game is set-up a series of merchandise values worth victory points are placed on nominated cities. The values of these tokens diminish when multiple tokens are present within a single city, requiring players to move quickly to capture the higher valued tokens.

These tokens can be collected by the players by placing their Passengers (3 per player), which can be achieved at the end of a turn in which a player lays trains to enter the city in question. Once a passenger is in play a player can forfeit their regular turn to move a passenger. Moving along a player's own train network comes at no cost and allows a player to take the top merchandise token from each city that is passed through. A passenger can also move along sections of track featuring other players trains but a passenger card must be paid each time this occurs to do so.

The player who completes the most destination tickets receives a 10 point bonus (instead of the base game's longest route bonus).

item.description:
An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

Dominox is played on a standard Chess/Checkers board using a standard set of Domino tiles. Only tiles with 0 to 6 dots are used. One player is designated 'white' while the other is 'black.' The players take turn placing tiles on the board, starting with the player who is dealt the lowest numbered double-tile, who must place this a his first move.

Tiles are placed according to the following restrictions:

* A tile must be placed such that it spans two squares (i.e., one half of the tile is on a black square and the other half is on a white).
 * No two tiles can share a square.
 * If a tile is placed next to another tile, the number of dots on the touching tile-end(s) must match that of its (their) neighbour. If a tile-end is next to several other tile-ends, only one of these need to match.

When there are no un-drawn tiles left and two passes in a row occur (i.e., both players pass), the game ends. At this point, the unfilled areas on the board are scored: Each connected unfilled area on the board counts to the color that is in majority in that area. If there is the same number of black and white squares, no player gets points for the area.

The player with the most points wins.

In Fire Drill, each player takes turns placing one of their pieces on any square on the board. The only limitation is that each piece must be at least one square away from a piece of the same color. Once all the pieces have been placed on the board, the starting player chooses any of his pieces to move. Play then alternates between opponents, each moving one of their own pieces. Pieces are moved in the fashion of the robots in Ricochet Robots. A piece travels in a straight line until it hits a wall or another piece, at which time it can turn left, right, or stop. A piece may make any number of turns and travel any distance in a turn, but once it stops, play proceeds to the next player.

The first player to align four of his pieces in a row orthogonally wins.

An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

Player 1 owns the black checkers, while player 2 owns the red checkers. Opponents alternate turns, as in most games. A 'king' is defined as in the game of Checkers: it is a stack of two checkers, of the same color. Kings cannot move but can be captured.

On his turn, a player chooses one of his own checkers to move. Moves are made vertically or horizontally, but not diagonally. A single move consists of picking up the chosen checker, jumping it over an opponent's checker or king (the jumped checker or king must be directly above, below, left, or right of the moving checker), and landing on an unoccupied square on the other side of the jumped checker. The jumped checker or king is then captured (removed from the board). On the same turn, a player may (but is not required to) continue moving this chosen checker in this way, until that checker cannot capture any more. A checker can only move if in so doing it captures an opponent's checker or king.

On his turn, after he has finished capturing, a player may use the checkers which he has just captured to transform some of his opponent's checkers into kings, by placing a single captured checker on top of a checker of the same color which is still on the board. The two checkers from a captured king can be used to make two new kings. A player can make as many kings on his turn as he has captured checkers.

The loser is the first player not able to move on his turn.

item.description:
An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

The worst fear of a Secret Service Agent is when the President of the US decides to leave an established motorcade and work the crowd. In this game, one player plays the President and his two Secret Service Agents and the other represents a crowd with an unknown assassin. Can you get the President through the crowd alive?

The President starts in one of the two center squares on one side of the board. He then places one Secret Service Agent on each side of the President. The crowd starts with 6 crowd members anywhere on the opposite half of the board.

Goal: The President player must exit from one of the two center squares on the opposite side of the board. The crowd player must assassinate the President.

This is a game for a standard piecepack.

Every year on the summer solstice the male yeti in the Himalayas have a contest to determine which one will be the head of the pack for the next year. This contest consists of a game of “King of the Hill” combined with a snowball fight. A yeti wins by being the sole occupant of the mountain peak for a full round of the game. Avoid the snowballs and don't fall off the cliffs.

This game uses a multi-level board of stacked tiles as the mountain and a Roborally like programmed movement system.

(From the box, weird punctuation and grammar preserved)

The Simpsons: Homer's Trivia Game

Hello, I'm Homer J. Simpson! Everybody knows that I have only two hairs on the top of my head (d'oh!) But do you know why I lost most of my hair? Or why my frumpy, old maid of a sister-in-law Selma has no sense of smell or taste? No? Well, don't fret like that pansy Flanders! (The answers are below!) Inside this box are lots more questions about Springfield's number one father, me.

You can compete with your friends, or other Simpson trivia-geeks (you know the type I'm talking about!) See who knows more about me (and what's more important than that?). It's more more fun than "Deviled-egg Nite" at Moe's Tavern!

And guess what? The game comes with a Simpsons cast poster. Whoo-hoo!

Answers:
Homer lost more and more hair each time one of his children were born
Selma lost her sense of taste and smell when a bottle rocket shot up her nose

It adds a musical theme for the series of Team Work Original games. It can be played as an expansion or stand-alone.

Expands:

 Team Work Original

From the publisher:

Welcome to a revolution in gaming! Savage Worlds is a merger of the best ideas in roleplaying and miniature games!

What's so revolutionary? We're glad you asked!

It's Fast! Savage Worlds is the fastest and easiest fully-detailed roleplaying game you'll ever play! You can fight out massive battles quickly and easily with your heroes, allies and minions in one simple, fast-playing system!

It's Furious! Characters gain awesome new abilities quickly, raising their attributes and skills and gaining powerful and exciting new Edges!

It's Fun! Savage Worlds was designed to be a Game Master's dream! GMs can write adventures, create new villains and monsters, and run epic tales, all without lots of bookkeeping. And you won't need computer programs, three rule books, and a half-dozen setting books to do it. You'll find everything you need right here and in the Savage Setting of your choice!

It's also a Miniatures Game! Savage Worlds works as a miniatures battle game as well as an RPG. That means you can fight out your heroes epic battles to save the world right on the table-top! Or you can play a competitive battle with troops of your own design!

It's Complete! Savage Worlds was designed to be used with any genre from swashbuckling pirates to superheroes and sci-fi. Inside you'll find complete and simple rules for epic heroes, vehicles, chases, magic, superpowers, mass battles, skirmishes, and even guidelines for designing your own races and worlds!

Expanded by:

 Tour of Darkness




As an RPG:
Savage Worlds can also be played strictly as a roleplaying game, and thus also exists as an rpggeek rpg entry.

item.description:
"All the thrills of a social season and a chance to be a .... Prom Queen"

A very cheaply made game by 'Built Rite'. The Senior Prom Game is a simple roll and move game for children. The game board is made out of thin cardboard and features 2 different tracks to move around depending on an initial spin with the spinner. Even the playing tokens are made out of cheap cardboard.

Some out of date and stereo-typical items are found on the game board including....

"Meet new boy at game. Wow! Run ahead 3 spaces."

"Dance with T.V. idol at sock hop. Move ahead 6 spaces."

"Study for finals with boy friend. Move ahead 2 spaces."

From the website:
In 1990, Saddam Hussein engineered the invasion and occupation of Kuwait, giving Iraq control of 24% of the world's oil supplies. January 1991, The United States and her allies launch Desert Shield and Desert Storm in an effort to remove the brutal dictator's forces from Kuwait. The First Gulf War was underway.

With the pieces from your "Axis & Allies" games and some others, then YOU can embark upon this 'Global' encounter. No longer is it restricted BY just the actual "Area of Operations", as the entire WORLD with 'this' has their 'say' for things. Declare a "Jihad!", tout your "Scientolo-dogma", "Kill for OIL!", it could ALL be there, so YOU 'be' there or be-hind!

This is a US Space Program flavored version of the classic board game. It comes with 8 customized tokens (satellite, astronaut, shuttle, lunar rover, space capsule, lunar lander, the Hubble, or the Mars Sojourner), a board with space program related destinations, hangars and space centers instead of houses and hotels, and Moon and Earth cards. It also features a complete mission manual with additional information on the US Space Program.

This is a game based in the 1989 movie starring Jack Nicholson and Michael Keaton, whose images feature in the graphics of the gameboard. Players can choose to be either a "Batman" or a "Joker", which determines their starting places and objectives. Batman must travel from Wayne Manor to the Batcave, and Joker must travel from Grissom's Apartment to Axis Chemical. Upon arrival, a Destination card is chosen, and the first player to reach their destination wins. There are cards drawn on various spaces (power, direction, and battle) that give advantages and players can battle an opposite character type with a die roll-vs-die roll contest to gain extra moves and cards.

Following Suit is a simple trick-taking game. The object is to collect as many points as possible in a single suit. The game is played in several rounds and the first player to reach 400 points wins.

Following Suit was one of the simultaneous-play games which began with Lamarckian Poker (published by GAMES Magazine in 1997 and previously free on the Cheapass website) and continued with Last Man Standing and Starbase Jeff. Following Suit was first published in Game Trade Monthly in 2000.

There are two different games inside the box: one on the field battle of Torino (7/9/1706) fought before the city and the other for the siege of the Cittadella (26/7 - 7/9/1706)itself.

The quality of the maps is not very high, while the counters (more than 500) are a work of art, with splendid reproduction of the period uniforms.
The rules are of medium complexity and of the usual kind for the field battle, while they seem very peculiar for the siege battle itself.

Players travel back and forth to Schiphol.

The person arriving back first wins.

Part of the game operates on the airport itself. After moving through check-in and security checks the player 'flies' to a destination and then flies back.
Has features in the game in order to try and stall or slow down the other players.

A very colorful mixture of RPG and Boardgame, this Brazilian game is designed for children of Ages 8 - 14 as an introduction to miniature games.

The game has rules for miniature battles between two or more participants. As in most miniatures games, players build an army with the same number of recruitment points (with each miniature having a different point value), then take turns moving and attacking until the opponent's forces are dead, withdrawn, or your pre-determined time limit expires.

The basic game has 11 classes to choose from, over 170 paper fold-out miniatures, 2 82x55cm colored maps and dozens of props.

The game is based on the Knights Templar´s history and mythology

Rare add-on for Avalon Hill's 'War at Sea (second edition)' and 'Victory in the Pacific' series but also a standalone game.

Includes (688) 1" square styrene counters that can be used with the original games or with the included (4) maps and a (48) page rulebook for combined global game. The maps are 21" x 27" and there are two Pacific and two Atlantic maps with a total of 39 areas.

As a standalone game, The Two Ocean War allows double-blind player movement via two copies of the Atlantic and Pacific theater maps. During the movement phase, players place their fleets on their own game boards, unaware of the other player's moves. Once moves are completed, both players go area by area on both maps, resolving battles between fleets placed in the same areas on the two different maps and to resolve combat and determine victory points awarded for each sea zone. Combat is similar to the Avalon Hill sea games, using six-sided dice. Rolls of 1-4 are no effect, 5 is a disable (ship returns to port), 6 is a hit causing a subsequent die roll for amount of damage.

The game is superior to the Avalon Hill sea games in some regards. Highlights include larger fleets (CL-class ships for all nations are represented in addition to the other ship classes in the AH games), more sea zones, and the blind movement resulting in often surprising battle lineups in particular sea zones. Additional rules let small ships torpedo big ones under certain conditions, and since the game represents fleets worldwide, there are opportunities for some Axis ships to change theaters just as the Allied ships can.

The Africa Edition has at present the best pre-constructed starters for History of War which are really a recommendation for new customers.

Although the Africa Edition consists of two pre-constructed decks for two players, the cards can of course be combined with all the other expansions of History of War. So the game - and all its expansions - can be played in multi-player sessions. The number of players may range from 2 - ?. There is no real limit, but the available place on most tables and the handling of some game mechanics usually do limit the player number to 6. Official multi-player rules don´t clarify that. It is recommended to play in two factions (axis and allies) with even player numbers - so 2, 4 or 6 players is best.

link.value: History of War: Italian Expansion Set
History of War: Russian Expansion Set

item.description:
New captains are sent to fight pirates.
Bold captains are sent to fight Klingons.
Only the clever Captains are sent to fight the crafty cloaked Romulans!

From the designer of Star Fleet Battles and Federation & Empire, Federation Commander: Romulan Border is a fast-moving game of starship combat in the Star Fleet Universe. This is not an 'introduction' to some other title. This is a product in an entirely new direction for the Star Fleet Universe, featuring production values expected by 21st-century gamers - mounted game maps, laminated full-color ship cards, full color counters, and laminated full-color play aids.

This is the second base set in the Federation Commander Series (Federation Commander: Klingon Border being the other). 
This is a complete game and does not require any other products for use. All other Federation Commander Products will work with Romulan Border.
 Components: 60-page Rev-4 rulebook, 216 half-inch and 20 one-inch full color die cut playing pieces, four full-color double-sided laminated player reference cards, sixteen full color double-sided laminated ship cards, six 8.5x11 hard-mounted double-sided map panels, two dice, paper clips for energy track, wipe-off marker. Improvements over Klingon Border: Higher-quality maps (now used in both products), real wipe-off marker, latest revision rulebook, expanded Sequence of Play.

It is far more than just "SFB Lite." It uses the best concepts from the best-selling space combat game of all time with Euro-Game production values and ease of play.

Key points include: 

 A typical duel takes one hour
 The largest fleet battles take four hours, not four days. 
 Energy is spent "on the fly" via a marker on a sliding scale. 
 Ship diagrams are laminated (multiple use, no photocopies!). 
 Color coded charts and ship cards make it easier remembering what goes where.
 Expansions include more ships, more scenarios, more maps - not complex new rules.

link.value: Star Fleet Battles: Module H1 – Megahex

name.value: Napoleon Dynamite: It's Pretty Much My Favorite Animal Game

item.description:
"It's pretty much my favorite animal. It's like a lion and a tiger mixed ... bred for its skills in magic."

If you drew a liger, would someone be able to guess that you combined a lion and a tiger to create it?

On your turn take two cards - each with a different animal name - and draw a combination animal - fast. If you get your teammates to guess what two animals you used, you move ahead on the game board. Heck, yes.

Land on Uncle Rico - IDIOT! - and you've got to show your next animal throwing a football. Land on Kip - Geez, I think you ripped my mole off! - and you have to combine THREE animals next time you draw.

The first player to get to the finish space wins.

item.description:
Can your fleet of numbered bees infiltrate the enemy hive and "buzz" the Queen Bee?
Higher numbered bees outrank lower ones. With a single "buzz," or touch, they move remove lesser bees from the hive. At number zero, the Queen Bee is practically defenseless.
Protect your Queen Bee from attack!
Steer clear of the dreaded fungus!
Watch out for the deadly Killer Bee!

Math skills covered: inequalities (greater than, less than), fractions, decimals, negative numbers, and place value.

This game is meant for use in grade 2 mathematics classrooms and beyond. The game is to be played by two players at a time. Players try to protect their queen bee from attack; steer clear of the black fungus; and avoid the deadly killer bee. Each player has nine worker bees with a whole number, fraction, or decimal value, one queen bee, and one killer bee. Players attack other bees of unknown value, and the bee with the higher value survives. Whoever captures their opponent's queen bee wins. Mathematics skills covered include inequalities; fractions; decimals; negative numbers; and place value. The game contains a game board, bee value cards, and playing piece stands.

Players are secret agents who try to be the one who defeats the evil guys located on an island in the center of the board. To do this they've to arrive there with a certain (secret) combination of microfilms (every player starts with 10 microfilms in his own color - different colors can be acquired by fighting other players). Agents travel around the board rolling a die and using transportation cards to acquire equipment cards and transportation cards to fight other players. Fights are resolved by secretly choosing up to two equipment cards - better equipment (total number) wins.

Before the race starts choose the setup of your car and the driver abilities guessing the right tires and the best engine setup to beat other players.

Play your cards and bring your car to the victory.
Every race will be different.

Contents:
94 modular elements to build every circuit you can dream of.
42 numbered chits
60 cards
3 dice
8 plastic cars in different colors
rules

item.description:
A game for the piecepack.

Operate a Taxicab in Pp City to earn more money then the other drivers in the Pp City "Best Taxi Driver" contest. This is a pick-up-and-delivery game with randomly generated passenger pick-up and destination addresses.

In Conquest of the Fallen Lands, you and your fellow players have a task to free a land invaded by vile hordes of monsters, and win back the treasures they plundered.

The game board is composed of hex tiles representing orc scouting parties, encampments, fortifications, dragons, etc. Each tile has a difficulty level.

Players take turns conquering these tiles by playing troop cards on them. Each conquered tile creates new opportunities to tackle tougher tiles around it, both for you and your opponents (so you have to be careful!).

Conquering a tile gets you a reward equal to its difficulty level. This money is used in the game to purchase assets and abilities, and it is also used to determine who has won this game, once it's over.

A number of magic cards introduce a variety of special effects and abilities that can greatly benefit the players.

The game includes two rule sets, Normal and Advanced, that play very differently:

 The Normal game is very accessible; it is a lighter game that plays with little downtime and yet has a lot of strategic depth. 
 The Advanced rules lead to a more complex game that can sometimes be a bit of a brain burner. It also moves at a much slower pace.

item.description:
You've just stumbled onto a small secret pond, hidden right in your own neighborhood. Three odd little creatures and their frog-friends are playing, and whatever their game is it's good! There's a duck made of paper, a bug trapped in a rock, and a toad spitting sparks from its tongue.

They're all squealing and jumping, leap-frogging and bumping, and racing the pond; oh what fun! Such tumbling and flapping and sparking and quacking; how you'd love to join the confusion. Then they all see you watching and ask you to play, and assure you it's not an intrusion.

Sizzletoad! is the game for two to four players (ages 5 and up) that combines rock-paper-scissors and tic-tac-toe with an exciting leap-frog race around the pond! There's a nice bluffing element as well (especially in the 2-player version).

Players duel with each other in rock-paper-scissors style using their 12-card hands of Fossilticks, Paperducks, and Sizzletoads to decide which player will be able to put cards on the lily pad pond, make a tic-tac-toe, and score the most victory points.

During the race around the pond the excitement builds as the players speed closer and closer to the flower at the finish-line! Care for a game of Sizzletoad! anyone?

This is a great game for parents to play with their kids when they're looking for a bit more variation and strategy than say, "Candy Land" or the like.

Here's a quick "How to Play" summary for the two-player game:

In a two player game, of Sizzletoad! the players shuffle and split the deck (which is filled with an equal number of Sizzletoads, Fossilticks, and Paperducks.)

Each round a single card is compared between the players and the winner of the duel puts either of those two cards onto the lily-pad tic-tac-toe grid of the board. The other card goes into that player's discard pile.

When one of the players places a matching "3-in-a-row" card on the tic-tac-toe grid, the other player counts the cards in his/her own discard pile, scores one point for each card and moves his/her game piece around the board by that many pips, then hands his/her cards over to the maker of the tic-tac-toe.

The maker of the tic-tac-toe then puts those cards into his/her own discard pile and adds them all up, scoring one point for each card and also moving his/her game piece around the board by that many pips.

All of the cards are then shuffled, re-dealt, and the players have another duel. The players continue dueling and adding cards to the board and their own discard piles and moving their game pieces around the numbered pips on the board.

The winner is the player who makes it all the way around the board onto or past the flowered lily-pad before the other player.

With easy game play, this solid game is a fine addition to any "children's'" game library.

Remember: Sizzletoad-beats-Paperduck-which-beats-Fossiltick-which-beats-Sizzletoad!

Sizzletoad! by Mindspan Labs (previously WizerGames) is Made in the USA

Mindspan Labs Digital has released a 1 and 2 player app version of Sizzletoad! that is now available in the Apple app store.

A trivia game for everyone! 700 fascinating trivia questions where every answer is a number between 1 and 10. Make big moves forward if your answer is correct. Take small steps if you're within one. Get it wrong and you'll have to move backwards. Be the first around the track and win!

Number 73 of edition Spielbox, issue 6 in 2005. Each player has the same set of 8 cards. These cards are placed around cauldrons to get points. The problem is - nobody nows which cauldrons are going to count at the end of the game.

item.description:
Fast-action family card game with a Science Fiction theme. Features a unique blend of strategy, skill, and chance.

Spaced Out is a fast-paced card game with exciting variables. "Cloning" is an exhilarating part of Spaced Out game play! Players are often on the edge of their seats, hoping to play out-of-turn, take extra turns, attack and defend against attacks. Utilize multiple scoring strategies. Every hand of SPACED OUT is unique, making the game enjoyable for different ages, size groups, and time-frames.

name.value: Warship Commander 1967-1987 Present Day Tactical Naval Combat

item.description: Sub-titled: "Present Day Tactical Naval Combat". Beginning with an excellent introduction about the evolution of 'Ships' from the "Post WW-2" era up until the 'present'-(circa 1979), and with some possible 'future' contingents. This is a set of RULES for use in conjunction with "Modern Naval Miniatures"(or 'counters') up to a scale of '1/1200th'-although others can be adapted for use as well. This is slightly larger than the norm-('11'&-3/4 by '8'&-1/2) sized "Rulebook" compilation, of 70-pages in length, with a 'slick'-cover for the contents. There is a 'section' which details just what will be required to enable any "playings" for this. Interspersed within the "Rules" are some "Tables" for comparison & explanations, with 'examples' also being shown. From page '42' and on, there are various "Charts", "Tables", the "Tactical Data Display"-sheet 'example' provided, the 'Bibliography', "Designer's Notes", with the "Table of Contents" on the last back '2'-pages for this. The scale given is '1'-vessel per 'mini' OR "counter", '2'-minutes per Turn, '1'-inch = 2,000 yds(m)-can also be scaled where more room is permitted.

The game includes a 5 3/4", 4 1/2", by 1 1/2" box that includes a 11" x 17" game map, 3 pages of rules, 55 cut-out U.S. counters, 63 cut-out Japanese counters, 18 flag markers, and a D10. The game is a type of expansion for Axis and Allies, but it might be possible to use this with other games too. An alternative scenario simulates the battle as if the U.S. had not broken the Japanese code.

This expansion doesn't seem to be an official expansion.

Expands:

 Axis & Allies

item.description:
This game is very similar to the The Game of Authors. The biggest difference appears to be that the names of the missing set cards are not provided on at the bottom of each card. The game can be used to teach job names to children.

This game was designed in England and was originally published for the Great Exhibition by John Jaques & Sons. The outside of the box described the name as Happy Families while the inside of the box describes the name as Merry Families. Each quartet consists of four family members -- a father, a mother, a son, and a daughter. The fathers are Mr. Daub the Painter, Mr. Dough the Baker, Mr. Pill the Doctor, Mr. Sand the Grocer, Mr. Saw the Carpenter, Mr. Snip the Barber, Mr. Stain the Dyer, Mr. Smut the Sweep, Mr. Thread the Tailor, and Mr. Tub the Brewer.

item.description: What is really stockpiled in museums all over the world? The people able to search the depots are interested in more than just Madonna sculptures or Biedermeier furniture. Real things are also hidden! Real mammoth bones, treasure chests, old toys and antique machines. Even parts of an old train can be found! A tactical dice game for three to six game players. The game features many very cool looking components.
An abstract game that many can play with pleasure, because the rules are really elementary! Limited release at Essen in 1998. Players place colored chips to form specific score-generating patterns.

The frogs of Froggy Bottom are having a race to see who is the fastest. Each frog will visit all five of his home lily pads and return to his starting place. The frog that does this first is the winner!

The object of the game, which is designed for a standard piecepack, is to visit each lily pad of your color and return to your home. When a lily pad of your color is reached, it is flipped to show the number side. When all of your symbols have been turned over and your frog returns to its
home pad, you win.

Online Play


 Super Duper Games

The chess-like board is mostly water, with "islands" in the middle. Each player has a homeland in a corner of the board with 3 ports.

Units are naval vessels, aircraft, air/naval bases and construction units.

Players purchase units with money and fight it out their military units to become the richest player by the end of the game.

A full set includes:

4 fact sheets (purchase prices, move/fire/range info)
Money (play money)
Equipment pieces for 4 countries
4 Flag markers
Generic air & naval base markers and damage markers
2 air-range measures
4 dice

I'm not sure how many of these were produced; mine is an original, mimeographed in a printed folder.

Based on the earlier 'Star Corps: Call to Battle'

Updated that game with new movement and combat rules and adds an alternating action system.

Includes:

Pink (black print) cover for the package
12-page rulebook
(5) counter & play aid cards
(10) cards with 4-6 unit status cards on each
(2) blank of the above (for personal mods)


 http://www.teamfrog.com/fig-sc.htm

In 1948, Parker Brothers indulged in a slight bit of overproduction when it introduced its version of the Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer game. Two to four players compete at this spin-and-move race to the chimney.

There are two editions to this game. One is a standard long-box game with a traditional foldout game board, featuring flat plastic reindeer on wooden stands. The other edition features a 3-D rooftop game board that sits atop the game box, with holes in the roof to insert the plastic reindeer for movement. Both editions include a wooden nose for Rudolph to help a player in moving through the cloud spaces.

The 3-D version also came with a Santa Claus sack of five jingle bells so that players could mark how many times they had won. I do not recall if the standard edition came with this sack.

You are Colonel Francis Marion (the Swamp Fox). Be the first player to capture three British Soldiers and return to Snow's Island.
Based on the Disney series.

For Ages 7 - 12, be the first to find his way through the maze. In addition to the walls of the maze, there are other hazards to avoid and the ability to jump over walls if the spinner lands on 'jump'

Book (150 pages) describes and analyzes nine two-player card games:
Piquet
Klaberjass
Demon Patience
Ecarte

From the game's introduction

"Shoestring Racer is a game about racing at the bottom end of the financial spectrum, where getting a bike built at all is a triumph of determination over lack of cash. The first part of the game represents the panic-stricken rushing around to get the racing goodies in the last fortnight before the racing season starts and the second part is the actual race, in which you discover whether your hastily assembled pile of bits is a potential winner."

Components
- Board featuring racetrack on one side, buildup grid on the other.
- 8 page rules booklet (A5 size).
- Movement Aid sheet (A4) giving examples of various moves.
- 2 decks of cards/tiles "Shop" and "Practice".
- pad of score sheets.
- plastic bike tokens.

Eugene en Italie (Eugene in Italy) is a DTP game, portraying the 1809 campaign of Prince Eugene (Napoleon's stepson) in Venetia. 
Units are brigades for infantry and regiments for cavalry. Three scenarios are provided, one on the battle of Sacile (15 turns), one of 9 turns on the clash on the banks of the Piave river, and a full campaign scenario of 45 turns.

Backyard Bug Buffet: Play this fun and easy game in which your insect species races to increase its population to the victory level, before the other players' species do!

Search the board for your required food, eat it or collect it, and breed young. Watch out for the predators out there though! They won't hesitate to gobble your six-legged animals!

Backyard Bug Buffet is a good introduction to the study and appreciation of insects, for children ages 6 and up.

Components:
1 washable felt mapboard
135 colored chips
40 plastic insects
56 food & predator tiles
6 species information cards
2 bonus predator information cards
rules
die

Game Ratings: non-aggressive, moderately competitive
Skill-Luck Ratio: 2:3

[Translated roughly from web pages]

A version of the the memory game for older participants than the classic game. Players try to find matches of tiles that have an association between two objects. One of the tiles is from a historical perspective and one from contemporary times. The play is meant to invoke discussions about the associations and provide a learning experience for those involved.

A Buffalo, NY Game. Made to commemorate an award winning news team for channel 7 WKBW-TV. On Front of Box:

Your chance to become a junior reporter for Eyewitness News! Be the first back to the station with all the facts and get your story on the air.

WKBW-TV Net proceeds donated to the Buffalo Variety club for Children's Hospital.

(This uses a one sided board, which is a redo of the Blizzard of '77 Travel game)

Based on curling, players move their two Sliders across the table or another smooth surface. Score 1 point for being closest to the edge, 2 points for a 'cliffhanger'. First player to score 10 points wins. Variant: use a target instead of the edge of the table.

Island War is a "Quadrigame" containing four separate battles:


 Bloody Ridge - Guadalcanal, Sept 1942 (designed by Kevin Zucker)
 Saipan - June 1944 (Kip Allen)
 Leyte - October 1944 (Jay Nelson)
 Okinawa - April 1945 (Larry Pinsky).


Each game is played on its own map. Counter density is fairly low and each map is folio sized. Includes Standard rules common to all four games and exclusive rules for each individual game. 400 counters

Just how well do you know your fellow players? Read a card with two words that describe another player. Serious or silly? Blizzard or hurricane? Can you guess which word is most like him? If so, you both score points! Play with those you think you know and those you'd like to know better.

link.value: Take Your Pick: Movies, Music, & More

item.description: Four games in one, this is no ordinary chess set. Take Chess to a whole new level! Add a new challenge to your game by adding the Frankencheck monster to the board in Frankencheck. Dig for treasures and uncover special points in Treasure Chessed. Or win UFO Spell Check by collecting letters, spell words, and add bonus words to the board. You may never want to play chess the same again!

name.value: The Great War in the West

item.description:
To The Last Man! is a strategic level wargame of World War 1 covering all aspects of the western front.

To The Last Man! uses cards to allow units to fight, take replacements and affect the course of the game with key technological, military, and political events. Players alternate playing cards and moving pieces. The game sequence is very interactive, with NO down time waiting for the other player to take his turn. The combat system has both players rolling dice in each combat.

In this two-player game each player starts the campaign game and 1914 scenario with cards that also represent the prewar stocks of ammunition, reserves and planning that allows the war to start off with a large bang. After players expend this allotment of cards, they must purchase more cards along with new units. Each player's resources are limited, so players often will not be able to launch large offensives every turn. They'll need to husband their resources. This represents the preparation for the next "Big Push." All of this leads to difficult game decisions all the way through the game.

There are scenarios for each year of the war from 1914 to 1918, along with the hypothetical Fuller or 1919 offensive. Also included are the many war plans conceived prior to the war and their appropriate set-ups so you could, for example, try the French 1909 plan vs. the German Schlieffen Plan.

Rules include: Great Offensives, Stosstruppen, tanks, gas attacks, cavalry, huge dogfights, reserves, siege guns, forts, events on other fronts, and much more.

item.description:
This is a very small, very inexpensive ($1.79) wargame covering the whole of the Thirty Years War. The three players represent Austria, Sweden, and the Palatinate. Production, political influence, and status are all kept on a small record sheet. The map and counters are made of paper. Victory is determined by victory points based on captured cities and aggregate political influence.

Obviously published on a shoestring, there's enough meaty game play here to have warranted a more substantial treatment.

name.value: The Margaret & David At The Movies Boardgame

item.description:
From the back of the box:

The Margaret & David At The Movies Boardgame takes the world's most popular pastime - watching movies - and turns it into a trivia battle supreme!

Inside this box you'll find 3600 questions about everything from Alien to Zoolander - with a few classics thrown into the mix.

You don't need to be a film buff to win. The clever gameplay means that everyone is kept in the picture and no-one ends up on the cutting room floor.

In fact, if your expertise only stretches to Dumb & Dumber you could still beat a player who has a PhD in the films of Martin Scorsese.

The game is a box-office smash that simply demands encore after encore!

item.description: This is a game about the war in AOI during the World War II (1940-41)

Tilt is yet another marble race game. The object of the game is to be the first player to move all four of his marbles around the board and into the center "home" area. The twist is that the board see-saws up and down depending on the position of the marbles. At the start, the board is perfectly balanced, but as the players move the marbles, the board tilts back and forth depending on the weight distribution of the marbles.

There are 18 "slide" areas around the board, and should your marble end up in one of these slides, a tilt of the board may send your marble forward or backward, or possibly right into the "home" area." (Think "Chutes and Ladders" with actual chutes.)

Though essentially a children's roll-and-move game, young players will quickly learn how to make the laws of gravity work for them. There is also some low-level strategy as players may choose to move their marbles backward if it would allow them to enter a slide.

Players compete to occupy the most valuable gold claims. This game was included in the July-September 2005 edition of Spielbox and requires colored stones or tokens and a deck of playing cards to play. Each turn, players have a number of points to move their stones along the track towards the gold claim spaces.

"The playing board is divided into four kingdoms (colored separately), each controlled by a different player. The object of the game is to conquer all the other kingdoms on the board and bring them under your rule."

1 Playing Board
4 Big Pegs
1 Die
50 Brown Foot Soldier Chips
30 Blue Horse Chips
20 Red Chariot Chips
20 Green Worker Chips
50 Big Yellow Chips (i.e. gold coins) with printed stickers of 5, 10 and 50
20 Calamity Cards

An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

Object: Be the first player to get two Kings off the far edge of the board. This is done by laying down a carpet of friendly Checkers for the Kings to jump.

Only one piece may be moved or introduced per turn. Checkers may be introduced onto any empty square. Alternatively, Checkers may move to any adjacent, empty square. A King may only move by jumping (in any direction) over friendly Checkers or Kings, capturing as he goes. Captured Checkers may be reintroduced later, but Kings that are captured do not return to the game.

The mechanics of jumping are the same as in the game Checkers, except that Kings may jump off the far edge of the board, into the 'end zone.' This King is removed from play. If a King has an opportunity to jump, he must jump, continuing until no more jumps are possible. So beware!

Winning: Victory is achieved when a player has jumped two Kings into the end zone.

Royal Carpet is an attempt to create a game of tempo in which friendly pieces have both positive and negative synergies. Crafty players will block jumps and then unblock them later, forcing an enemy King to jump his royal brethren. For those so inclined, this game is fun to play with a backgammon doubling cube, held initially by the Red player.

An entry in the 2001 About.com 8x8 Game Design Competition.

The sibling rivalry between you and your brother is legendary. Some ascribe the antagonism to the circumstances of your birth: When the Queen bore identical twins sons many years ago, a careless midwife placed both infants in the same bassinet without identifying the elder, and the rightful heir to the throne has been in doubt ever since. Others believe that your fierce competitiveness is simply a distillation of the belligerence that runs throughout your bloodline. For whatever reason, you have spent your entire life trying to prove your superiority to your brother.

Unfortunately, that life is about to end.

Four days ago Barbarians attacked from the west. Both you and your brother marshaled your individual forces and followed your father to meet the enemy. At first it seemed the battle would be easily won: for each of your soldiers who fell in battle a score of Marauders were dispatched. But by the third day it became apparent that, while your own forces rapidly dwindled, there would be no end to the Barbarian horde. And this morning your losing battle quickly became a rout: The King was slain, you found yourself surrounded, and the forces controlled by you and your brother were reduced to a mere handful a piece.

Now, as the Marauders press in, you know that you will soon be sent to your reward. But you don't fear death. In fact, only one thing weighs on your mind: this is your absolute last chance to outdo your brother. And you are certain he is thinking the same thing.

Object: Each player will attempt to amass more Kills than his opponent before both Princes die in battle.

Reference cards are also provided but not required.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable
